title: 110_s941
content: The Act may be cited as the "Community Health Centers Investment Act". Congress finds that 35,000,000 Americans lack access to basic health services, especially those in underserved rural or urban areas, without insurance or ability to pay. This leads to high infant mortality, low immunization rates, and overuse of emergency rooms for primary care. Community health centers, serving over 16,000,000 needy Americans in 5,000 communities, have proven to be effective in providing high-quality care with cost-efficiency. Nearly 900 underserved communities were funded in the past 5 years to establish these centers. In the past 5 years, nearly 900 underserved communities were funded to establish health centers, providing care to almost 5,000,000 needy individuals. However, 800 communities approved for centers were not funded due to lack of available funding. Existing health centers have faced reduced Federal grant support, jeopardizing their sustainability and ability to meet the needs of the uninsured. Growing new centers without supporting existing ones weakens this valuable resource for disadvantaged Americans. Health centers rely on the National Health Service Corps for over 20 percent of their physician workforce, but fewer than half of all Corps placements are made to health centers. Health centers experienced a 15 percent physician vacancy rate and a 19 percent dentist vacancy rate nationally, with higher rates in rural areas. Adequate reimbursement for services is crucial for health centers. Adequate reimbursement is crucial for health centers to fulfill their mission, as their Medicare payments are subject to an outdated cap, causing significant annual revenue losses nationally. SEC. 3. COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS. Funding for the program authorized under section 330 of the Public Health Service Act is as follows: $2,563,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, $2,863,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $3,263,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $3,663,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, $4,163,000,000 for fiscal year 2012, $4,663,000,000 for fiscal year 2013, $5,263,000,000 for fiscal year 2014, and $5,863,000,000 for fiscal year 2015. Amounts appropriated shall be used according to specified priorities. Priority for operating grants under section 330 of the Public Health Service Act is given based on eligibility requirements. An adjustment may be provided to account for increased costs per encounter. Priority for operating grants under section 330 of the Public Health Service Act is based on eligibility requirements, with consideration for increased costs per encounter and changes in the number of users at health centers. Third priority is given to initial or expanded operating grants for eligible applicants for New Access Point or Expanded Medical Capacity grants. Priority for operating grants under section 330 of the Public Health Service Act is based on eligibility requirements, with consideration for increased costs per encounter and changes in the number of users at health centers. Fourth priority shall be given to providing initial operating grants to eligible applicants for New Access Point or Expanded Medical Capacity grants during fiscal years 2002 through 2007. The criteria for approving applications for New Access Point or Expanded Medical Capacity grants in fiscal year 2008 prioritize equitable geographic distribution among grantees who received a score of "Fully Acceptable" or better from an Objective Review Committee. Priority is given to supporting the planning and development of new health centers in communities demonstrating need under section 330 of the Public Health Service Act. Funds are used to award grants to entities that will serve medically underserved populations. Entities eligible for grants must serve medically underserved areas based on specific criteria such as distance from other sources of care, lack of access to existing practices, disparities in health status, and barriers to primary health care. Up to $20,000,000 of the grant amount can be allocated to support health center networks. The grant program supports health center networks or organizations representing all health centers in a State to establish statewide systems ensuring health centers in all underserved areas. Funding criteria for approving applications must ensure equitable geographic distribution among grantees' service areas. Funds are distributed annually according to specified priorities. SEC. 4. NATIONAL HEALTH SERVICE CORPS. Funding for programs authorized under sections 331 through 338G of the Public Health Service Act is as follows: $150M for 2008, $175M for 2009, $200M for 2010, $225M for 2011, $250M for 2012, $275M for 2013, $300M for 2014, and $325M for 2015. Amendments are made to the assignment of personnel in the Public Health Service Corps. The Secretary shall not discriminate against applications from entities not receiving Federal financial assistance under this Act. Preference will be given to applications where a nonprofit or public entity provides a site for Corps members, with the highest preference for federally qualified health centers and entities serving minority and health disparity populations. The Secretary shall prioritize applications from entities providing sites for Corps members, with a preference for federally qualified health centers and those serving minority and health disparity populations. The assignment of corps personnel will give preference to applications as set forth in subsection (a)(3) of section 333. The Public Health Service Act is amended to revise scholarship limitations, requiring the Secretary to allocate at least 40% of funds for awarding scholarships, including those for individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds. SEC. 5. MEDICARE. Coverage for FQHC Ambulatory Services under the Social Security Act is expanded to include a range of services provided by Federally qualified health centers, including preventive primary health services required by the Public Health Service Act. The Social Security Act is amended to include payment requirements for Federally qualified health centers, with changes effective from January 1, 2007.
